Toyline general info:
>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figma

Max Factory figma list & blog
>http://www.figma.jp/en/figma
>http://ameblo.jp/figma/
>http://www.goodsmile.info/en/products/category/figma

Reviews and news about GSC/MF products by Kahotan
>http://mikatan.goodsmile.info/en/
>http://ameblo.jp/gsc-mikatan/

Where to buy
>GSC Online Shop - some figmas only are available through their online shop
>Amiami - usual place for buying, to some people, shipping is a bit higher due to packaging
>Hobby Link Japan shipping is usual lower, but their prices are a bit higher, private warehaouse is available
>Hobby Search Japan - items stay in stock the longest
>Mandarake - search figma or フィグマ
>eBay/Amazon - only if you hate having too much money. Avoid bootlegs, you can spot them as 'Chinese version'
>http://jungle-scs.co.jp/ - Seems like you can fine some good deals here
>Check the BST threads, My Figure Collection for any offer/deal

Here's a link to the buyfag guide list of shops:
http://www.buyfags.moe/Full_guide#List_of_shops
If you're getting into the hobby, there's plenty of other useful information to find on the wiki.

In case someone is interested in the printable backdrops/dioramas & other papercraft stuff that Max Factory have in the download section of their site:
>http://www.maxfactory.jp/ja/mxf-downloads
here is a back up, Enjoy!
>https://www.mediafire.com/?7l9ar0z58cx43sa

Short illustrated posing guide by Max Factory
>http://ameblo.jp/figma/entry-11564427757.html (in moonrunes)
The S shape is always good advice though. The basic idea is that straight lines tend to look stiff.

Problems when swapping parts/accessories with your figmas? Check this advice
>http://www.goodsmile.info/en/post/3325

Tomytec's 1 inch scale section (1/12 stuff, little armory, vehicles and others)
>http://www.tomytec.co.jp/1inch/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10144344
Don't do any drilling at all like the other people are saying. First try the least invasiive approach with the lowest opportunity of damaging it more and try to dunk the upper arm in almost boiling water to soften it a little and then stick something super thin like one of those needle-dental or sculpting tools. Work it inbetween the broken joint and the socket at various points around in there to try to wiggle it out slowly. Then just remove the other half of the broken joint from the forearm and replace with a new Figma Joint. Or use one of those Hobby Base joints that's the same size. They don't have any light blue ones though so I'm not sure what you'd be able to do as far as color matching.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10144800
For color matching you have to do what customizers have had to do for 2 decades. Sand/grind the rings down so that they're thin enough for paint to not rub against the PVC, and then paint the joint.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10145038
Paint notoriously has a harder time adhering to POM that those joints are made of so fyi before you lead to some potential frustration

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10145118
I'm not entirely sure what plastic the joints are made of for Figma toys, but in the projects I've worked on with other toys it reminds me of nylon. High melting point, generally a bit more flex and scratch resistance, and no reaction to acetone which is why it's so hard to make paint stick to it.

The secret weapon to painting any surface that does not want to take paint is to rough it up with sandpaper. The type of paint you use can make a huge difference too, but the most reliable technique I've had has always been to sand (or dremel grind) the joints until I'm sure the outer rings won't rub against the main material of the toy, and then scuff it up with some 300 grit sanding sticks or sand paper. Painted joints will never be as resient as ones that were molded in the correct color but as long as you aren't giving it to a young kid to play with in the sandbox, you'll usually get good results. And, even though joint material generally does not react with acetone, priming them does help.

We had a really comfy LOTR toys thread here a while ago. As said before, the original line from 2001-2005 still holds up really well, especially some of the later figures when Toybiz started moving away from action gimmicks to 30POA (they're essentially Marvel Legends style figures), and they're actually still quite affordable to collect, with a few exceptions (the Balrog).

There's not really a lot of new stuff to talk about with LOTR toys although Diamond Select did just come out with their 8" deluxe figures. There's no toys for "that show" and there probably won't be (good riddance). Once in a while it's nice to have a thread to catch up on how fellow LOTR anons' collections are going though. What scenes do you want to recreate? Are you army building? Doing any customs and conversions to complete your collection? Have you come across any cool boomer LOTR merch from before the movies? Let's take a moment to celebrate that this beloved book series got the action figure line it deserved.

threads.name: Santa Man
threads.com:
It's November 1st, so you know what that means. It's time for /toy/ Secret Santa 2022!

There doesn't appear to be as many shipping delays this year but I'm still making the cut off for sign up November 6th like last year because it worked out well and gives everyone through the weekend to sign up. I will try to have assignments out by the 7th or the 8th at the latest.

There are some small changes to SS this year though:
>The budget has been changed from 25-35 usd to 30-40 usd
>Proof of purchase will now require you to send me a picture of your gift with a timestamp before I give it the ok along with the receipt
>I will not be pairing up Canadians domestically due to issues in the past. Those who wish to ship domestic will be paired with people in the US. Sorry for the inconvenience.

For more info on these changes check the FAQ as I've detailed it there for the exception of the price change because the explanation for that is very simple. I picked out the original 25-35 price range several years ago and after years of running the event I felt bumping the price up by 5 dollars better reflects what people actually spend on the event, that's all.

My email: toysecretsanta2022@gmail.com
Sign-up form: https://forms.gle/yXbEEiFmu8t1xTs77
FAQ: https://pastebin.com/jA4SUZUQ

last_replies.com:
>>10142829
If they would just take The Mass Device, make it a half hour longer and give it more adult sounding dialogue, and shoot it in live action, you'd have a $500 million-$1 billion blocbuster. The story is not any dumber than a Marvel movie, it just has dialogue that sounds like a kid's show. It's got big high-concept, high stakes action sequences, believable peril for the heroes, and a cast of memorable characters that it manages to bounce around between without anyone feeling lost.

In short, it holds up surprisingly well and proves to me that GI Joe could be a great movie franchise if they don't fuck it up and try to hide what it is that people love about it. Sure, you could argue it's military propaganda, but with how much everyone in the USA hates each other right now is it really such a bad thing to have a story about very different people who all work together because they love their country? Isn't that what GI Joe was really saying for being ahead of its time in terms of featuring racial and ethnic diversity, while still championing the ideas of patriotism and love for your fellow countrymen?

threads.com: Anyone know any worm or tentacle monster toys? Preferably ones that can eat other figures.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10137346
>mfw finally help a fellow /toy/anon
Feels good man

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10133806
Hasbro Rathtar came in and I finally had a chance for some quick testing today.

You have to put on the tentacles yourself. They are hard PVC-like plastic with some flexibility to them. As I expected soaking them in hot water makes them completely bendable and they will hold their shape once cooled down (pic related, before and after wrapping around the included figure). As they remain slightly flexible overbending is recommended to get tight grabs. The tentacles have different lengths, which straightened out they vary from 10 to 15cm. 2 of the tentacles have "grabber" tips, the others classic rounded tips.

The pegs and pegholes used for the tentacles are all the same shape and size so you can freely mix and match positions as you please, even if the instructions specify a specific order. However the tentacles are prone to falling off when inserted cold. Instead you want to heat up the pegs which gives them way a better fit. The instructions don't mention this which explains all the complaints from angry parents. As for movement, it only allows for rotation.

The mouth and teeth are soft PVC. The mouth's opening is 27mm wide and 22mm tall. The body is hard plastic and hollow. Measured from the mouth it goes 86mm deep. The sculpt has a lot of details which would benefit from a wash.

At €15 (€10 post gift card) I'd say it makes for a nice affordable option for degenerate uses. It might be annoying to pose and a bit small for larger figures, but definitely useable. Now to decide what figure I want to pose with it...
